text:
Hi All,
Just a quick question about syntax. From what I understand, using filldist is more performant than for loops. I am unsure if/how to translate this to use filldist:

`for i ∈ 1:length(predicted)`
        `data[:,i] ~ MvNormal(predicted[i], σ)` 
`end` 
where `predicted` is the solution to an ODEProblem and has size `(5,101)` .

Any suggestions appreciated! :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text:
Hi All,
Just a quick question about syntax. From what I understand, using filldist is more performant than for loops. I am unsure if/how to translate this to use filldist:
is the solution to an ODEProblem and has size

text: I don't think `filldist` will work here (or really in general for likelihoods). It samples an arbitrary number of draws i.i.d from the underlying distribution, but here your distribution changes based on the prediction at `i` , thus not i.i.d.

elements.text: will work here (or really in general for likelihoods). It samples an arbitrary number of draws i.i.d from the underlying distribution, but here your distribution changes based on the prediction at

text: You could try treating it as a matrix-valued likelihood, but I'm not sure that will be more efficient. The way you have it written looks correct for this use case.

elements.text: You could try treating it as a matrix-valued likelihood, but I'm not sure that will be more efficient. The way you have it written looks correct for this use case.

text: Ok, I’ll leave it as is then. Thank you!

elements.text: Ok, I’ll leave it as is then. Thank you!
